message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common CFTR mutation, F508del, leads to defective post-translational glycosylation of the CFTR channel, resulting in a misfolded protein that is rapidly degraded. This leads to a loss of function of the CFTR channel, which is important for ion transport in various tissues, including the lungs and digestive system. Insufficient production, hydroxylation or phosphorylation are not the main pathogenic processes in cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common CFTR mutation, Delta F508, results in defective post-translational glycosylation of the CFTR channel, which leads to misfolding and degradation of the protein in the endoplasmic reticulum. This results in decreased production of functional CFTR channels on the cell surface, leading to the characteristic symptoms of cystic fibrosis. Insufficient production is not the main issue, as there are functional CFTR channels that are not properly trafficked to the cell surface. Hydroxylation and phosphorylation are not involved in the pathogenesis of cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common mutation in CFTR gene is the deletion of phenylalanine at position 508 (F508del) which leads to defective post-translational glycosylation of the CFTR channel, causing abnormalities in channel folding and trafficking. This results in insufficient chloride transport across epithelial cells, leading to the characteristic symptoms of cystic fibrosis. Therefore, option (B) is correct. Option (A) is incorrect because in cystic fibrosis, there is actually an overproduction of the defective CFTR channel. Options (C) and (D) are also incorrect as they do not play a role in the pathogenesis of cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common CFTR mutation is known as ΔF508, which leads to a defective post-translational glycosylation of the CFTR channel. This in turn affects the stability and function of the channel, leading to the characteristic symptoms of cystic fibrosis. Option (A) is incorrect because there is actually an overproduction of the defective CFTR channel. Options (C) and (D) are also incorrect because they involve other post-translational modifications that are not affected by the ΔF508 mutation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common CFTR mutation is the delta-F508 mutation, which affects post-translational glycosylation of the CFTR channel, leading to a misfolded protein and faulty channel function. Option A is incorrect because there is normal or increased CFTR production, but the protein is not functional. Option C and D are also incorrect as they do not affect glycosylation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common CFTR mutation leads to defective post-translational glycosylation of the CFTR channel, which impairs its function and causes the symptoms of cystic fibrosis. Insufficient production, hydroxylation, or phosphorylation are not the primary mechanisms involved in cystic fibrosis pathogenesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common CFTR mutation is a deletion of a phenylalanine residue from the CFTR protein (F508del), which causes defective post-translational glycosylation of the CFTR channel. This leads to misfolding and degradation of the protein, resulting in reduced or absent function of the CFTR channel.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common CFTR mutation leads to defective post-translational glycosylation of the CFTR channel, which affects its proper folding and function. This leads to impaired chloride ion transport across cell membranes, leading to thick and sticky mucus in various organs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common mutation for cystic fibrosis is the delta F508 mutation which leads to defective post-translational glycosylation of the CFTR channel, ultimately resulting in its misfolding and degradation. This leads to reduced activity of the CFTR channel, which impairs ion transport across epithelial cells, causing the characteristic symptoms of cystic fibrosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common mutation causing cystic fibrosis is a deletion of phenylalanine at position 508 (F508del) which leads to defective post-translational glycosylation of the CFTR channel. This results in abnormal chloride and water transport across epithelial cells leading to thick, sticky mucus in various organs.
